summary: This is a status update memorandum from the Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) to the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) regarding the BOP's response to eight recommendations from the OIG's final report on the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The memorandum states that all eight recommendations are considered 'Resolved' based on the BOP's reported actions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody, care, and supervision at the Metropolitan Correctional Center was the subject of the original OIG investigation and report.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the Federal Bureau of Prisons' custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: BOP Status Update Submission
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons provided a status update to the OIG in response to the eight recommendations from the June 26, 2023, final report.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's final report, dated June 26, 2023, contained eight specific recommendations for the BOP regarding inmate custody procedures, largely prompted by the case of Jeffrey Epstein.
All eight recommendations are currently marked as 'Resolved' by the OIG based on the BOP's September 11, 2023, status update describing planned or ongoing actions.

The recommendations focus on critical procedural gaps, including assigning cellmates after suicide watch, ensuring high-risk inmates have cellmates, visit approval processes, inmate accountability methods, lieutenant round requirements, staffing shortages, cell search procedures, and security camera functionality.

The BOP reported it is developing new guidance (a 'CEO memo') in collaboration between its Reentry Services Division and Correctional Programs Division to address housing and cellmate assignment procedures following suicide watch.
The BOP is actively implementing recruitment and retention incentives, including a $10,000 or 25% salary recruitment bonus for new Correctional Officers, to address staffing shortages.
